File.Title: The Intercollicular Pathway in the Golden Hamster: An Anatomical Study
File.Authors: E. FISH, DIANNE K. GOODMAN, DAVID C. KUO, JEFFREY POLCER, AND ROBERT W. RHOADES

Abstract.S: The intercollicular pathway of the hamster was studied by means of a combination of horseradish peroxidase (HRP), autoradiographic, and double-labeling (nuclear yellow-HRP) techniques.
Small deposits of HRP marked significant numbers of cells in the contralateral colliculus only when the injection site included the laminae ventral to the stratum opticum.
Anterior deposits labeled many more neurons than injections into the caudal part of the tectum.
Of the cells labeled by our injections, 18.2% were located in the superficial collicular laminae (stratum griseum superficiale and stratum opticum), and the remainder (81.8%) were in the deep layers.

A wide variety of morphological cell types contributed axons to the intercollicular projection, and in a given animal the loci of the labeled neurons were generally symmetrical with the injection site.
Small deposits of [3H]-leucine resulted in contralateral labeling only when the injection included the deep collicular laminae.
The transported label was most dense in the stratum griseum intermediale and stratum griseum profundum, and its location was generally homotopic with the injection site.

Experiments in which collicular HRP deposits were combined with large cervical spinal or pontine reticular injections of Nuclear Yellow indicated that intertectal neurons did not, in most cases, contribute axon branches to the spinal or pontine reticular projections of the colliculus.

Receptive field data obtained at the time of the HRP and/or [3H]leucine deposits demonstrated that the collicular representations of the ipsilateral and at least 45" of the contralateral hemifields were encompassed by intercollicular connections.
This was also true for the somatosensory representation of the entire head and a portion of the neck.

Introduction.S: In 1966 Sprague demonstrated that removal of the posterior neocortex in cat resulted in a profound contralateral hemianopsia which could be reversed by destruction of superior colliculus contralateral to the damaged cortex or section of the intertectal commissure.

Sprague's findings have been replicated both in cat (Sherman, '74, '77) and rodents (Kirvel et al., '74; Schneider, '751, and "neural correlates" of this effect have also been reported in several mammals (Goodale, '73; Saraiva et al., '76; Nagata et al., '80).
The intercollicular pathway, while thought to be intimately involved in the Sprague effect (Sprague, '66; Sherman, '74; Edwards, '77; but see Nagata et al., '80 for an D.
opposing view), has been the subject of only a handful of anatomical experiments.

Only in cat (Edwards, '77; Magalhses-Castro et al., '78; Maeda et al., '791, and, to a lesser extent, rabbit (Nagata et al., '80), have intertectal connections been studied with axoplasmic transport techniques.

In these two species, both of which demonstrate phenomena (see above cited references) suggestive of the intertectal inhibition postulated by Sprague ('661, the results have been strikingly different.
In cat (again, see the references cited above) the rostra1 portions of the two colliculi are richly interconnected.
In rabbit, on the other hand, horseradish peroxidase (HRP) tracing experiments provided no evidence of intercollicular connections.

In view of these surprising species differences we have investigated intercollicular connections in the hamster, another mammal for which behavioral phenomena similar to those demonstrated by Sprague have been reported (Schneider, '75).

Methods.S: METHODS
Surgical procedures

Each hamster (73 normal adults, 6-9 months of age) was anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (60 mg/kg, delivered intraperitoneally with 0.10 ml of a 1.5% solution of atropine sulfate) and placed in a stereotaxic headholder.
The scalp was slit and a small hole was drilled in the skull over the right superior colliculus.
An injection was made in the manner described below, the scalp was closed with wound clips, and the animal was returned to its home cage.
Injections and tissue processing

HRP experiments In six hamsters 10-90 nl of HRP (Sigma type VI, a 30%, w/v, solution in distilled water) was pressure injected through pipettes having tip diameters between 25 and 40 pm (see Fish and Rhoades, '81a for details).
In another 22 animals, HRP (a 25% solution dissolved in 0.5M, tris-buffered KC1, pH 7.6) was electrophoresed into the colliculus with a Midgard CS-3 constant current unit.
Injection current was 1 pA (7 seconds on, 7 seconds om and injection times ranged between 7 and 15 minutes.
All injection sites were verified physiologically either by recording through the pipette or with a tungsten electrode just prior to the insertion of the pipette.
After 24-48 hours, hamsters were reanesthetized and perfused transcardially according to the method of Rosene and Mesulam ('78).

The brainstem was then sectioned frozen in the frontal plane at 40-50 bm, processed for HRP according to the method of Mesulam ('78), and counterstained with either neutral red or thionin (Adams, '80).

Autoradiographic (ARG) experiments In nine cases, 5-15 nl of [3Hl-leucine (Spec. act. 118 Ci/mM, final concentration 20 pCi/pI, dissolved in distilled water) was pressure injected in the manner described above.
In 13 animals electrophoretic methods were used.
Here L3H1-leucine (20 FCi/kl) was dissolved in 0.01 M acetic acid and deposited as described above.
All injection sites were defined physiologically.
After 2 to 5 days, animals were reanesthetized and perfused with 0.9% saline followed by 10% formalin (in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4).

The brains were immediately removed, allowed to sink in 30% sucrose-formalin, blocked, sectioned frozen (50 Fm) in the frontal plane, and processed for autoradiography using the methods described by Cowan et al. ('72).
Following exposure for between 8 and 12 weeks, the slides were developed in D-19, washed, fixed, counterstained with cresylecht violet, dehydrated, cleared, and coverslipped.

Combined HRP-ARG experiments Here, a solution composed of 20% HRP and t3H1-leucine (other parameters defined above) was pressure injected into a physiologically defined locus in the right superior colliculus.

After 2 days, the animals were perfused by the method of Rosene and Mesulam ('781, the brain was immediately cut in the frontal plane (33 pm), and alternate sections were processed for HRP or ARG in the manners described above.

HRP-nuclear yellow (NY) experiments These experiments were carried out in order to determine whether or not intertectal neurons contributed axons branches to the spinal or pontine reticular outputs of the colliculus.

In 12 animals, HRP was electrophoresed into the right superior colliculus in the manner described above, and 0.2-0.6 p1 of NY (a 2% w/v, solution in distilled water) was injected into either the upper cervical spinal cord (five hamsters) or into the pontine reticular formation (seven hamsters) using a Hamilton syringe (31-gauge needle).

In two other hamsters, NY (0.1 p1) was injected into the superior colliculus and crystalline HRP was placed in a cut in the upper cervical spinal cord (see Rhoades and DellaCroce, '80 for methodological details).

After 16 hours (see Bentivoglio et al., '80) hamsters were perfused with 0.9% saline, followed by 4% paraformaldehyde (in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4) and then 10% sucrose (w/v, in the same buffer).
Brains and cervical spinal cords (where appropriate) were immediately removed and sectioned (20-40 Fm) in the frontal plane.
Alternate sections were collected in either distilled water or chilled (4°C) phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).

The sections collected in water were mounted immediately on uncoated slides while the other set was reacted for HRP, mounted on gelatin-coated slides, and coverslipped using either HFM fluorescence mounting medium or paraffin oil.
This combination of tracers was employed because of the necessity for relatively small injection sites and minimal tissue damage in the colliculus.
This requirement was most readily met by using HRP and electrophoretic techniques for the collicular tracer deposits.
Data analysis
All sections were examined using a photomicroscope equipped with brightfield, darkfield, and episcopic fluorescence optics.
Section outlines and laminar boundaries were drawn using a drawing tube, and injection sites, HRP-labeled cells, and autoradiographic labeling were plotted on these drawings.
Dorsal view drawings were constructed according to the methods described by Chalupa and Rhoades ('79).
For the double-labeling experiments, sections were examined with a combination of fluorescence (excitation wavelength = 360 nm) and brightfield optics.
Cells were considered to be double labeled only if cytoplasmic HRP labeling and nuclear and nucleolar NY labeling were both visible in the same plane of focus at a total magnification of x 400.'

In order to assess the possibility that the time required for the HRP incubation and reaction (approximately 40 minutes) resulted in diffusion of NY labeling (see Bentivoglio et al., 'go), the collicular labeling in adjacent reacted and unreacted sections was compared.
No clear differences were noted between the two sets of sections.
Cell areas were computed using a Zeiss MOP I11 semiautomatic image analyzer.

Results.S: RESULTS
HRP experiments

Areal and laminar distribution of intertectal neurons The HRP experiments revealed that intertectal neurons were located predominantly in the deep laminae ( i . e . , the layers ventral to the stratum opticum ( SO ) ) of the rostral one - half of the colliculus , and that intertectal axons probably terminated in the anterior portion of the deep tectal layers , in mirror symmetry with the locations of their cells or origin .

TTE.S: In HTN - 80 ( Figs . 1,2 ) an HRP deposit was centered 600 Frn from the rostral collicular boundary , 2 in the SO , with some spillage of tracer in the SGS and most dorsal portion of the SGI .
Only one labeled cell was seen in the contralateral tectum of this animal .
In the five cases where HRP injections were confined to the superficial layers of the rostral colliculus , only 14 labeled neurons were visible on the contralateral side .
The laminar distribution for these cells is provided in Table 1.
In HTN-51, the HRP deposit was centered in the rostral SGI.
Here a number of labeled neurons were visible in the contralateral tectum , most of which were in the deep layers ( Fig . 2 ) .
The ten cases with injections centered in the deep , rostral colliculus resulted in a total of 211 labeled cells .
Eighty - seven percent of these neurons ( Table 1 ) were located in the deep laminae .
In these cases , the distributions of labeled intertectal neurons closely matched the locations of the injection sites .
This correspondence is illustrated by the dorsal view reconstructions provided in Figure 3.
It can also be seen , however , that medial injections ( e . g . , HTN - 51, HTN - 60 ) labeled a number of cells in the lateral part of the contralateral colliculus .
It may be that these neurons were labeled as a result of damage to and transport of HRP by fibers passing through the injection site to terminate more laterally .
This suggestion is supported by the fact that lateral HRP deposits ( e . g . , HTN62 ) resulted in few or no labeled cells in the medial part of the contralateral tectum .
No labeled intertectal cells were observed following HRP injections into the superficial layers of the caudal one - half of the colliculus ( HTN - 34, Figs . 1, 2, Table 1 ) .
When posterior injections included the deep laminae (HTN-42, Figs. 1, 2) such cells, however, were visible.
In the seven cases with injections centered in the caudal - deep colliculus , a total of 60 labeled cells was obtained ( Table 1 ) .
In these animals , 30.0% of all labeled cells were located in the SO , whereas only 12.3% of the labeled neurons obtained with the rostral - deep injections were found in this layer .
A statistical comparison of the laminar distributions of labeled intertectal neurons in these two conditions demonstrated that they were reliably different ( X2 = 28.1, df = 5, P & > 0.01 ) .
The areal distributions of the labeled cells obtained with deep-caudal injections were much more diffuse than those observed with rostroventral injections.
This is illustrated by the dorsal view reconstructions in Figure 3.
We attempted to quantify this apparent difference between the two groups of animals by taking a mirror image of the CAUDAL INJECTIONS

dorsal view of the colliculus which received the HRP deposit , fitting its borders to those of the contralateral colliculus , and counting the number of cells which fell within or touched the borders of the injection site ( both the solid and shaded regions ) .
While such an analysis may be partially confounded by variability in injection size and transport of HRP by cut fibers of passage , a clearcut difference between the two sets of data was apparent .
With the rostral injections, an average of 59.5% ( & 15.0) of the labeled cells fell within the borders of the injection site.
With the caudal injections, this vaiue fell to 34.9% (% 13.6) (U = 6.5, P < 0.01).
Morphology of intertectal neurons. A wide variety of cell types contributed axons to the intertectal pathway .
In the superficial laminae , cells with vertically ( Fig . 4E ) and horizontally ( Fig . 4F ) oriented dendritic trees projected to the contralateral superior colliculus .
These two cell types are similar to the horizontal and vertical fusiform cells described in Golgi studies of the rat_s superior colliculus ( Langer and Lund , 74 ; Tokunaga and Otani , 76 ) .

In the deep layers labeled neurons with vertically ( Fig . 4H ) and horizontally ( Fig . 41 ) oriented dendritic trees were also observed , along with a number of multipolar cells ( Fig . 4A , B , G , J ) .
The size distribution for the cell bodies of labeled intertectal neurons was quite broad , with cell areas ranging between 68 pmZ and 435 pm2 ( X = 138.4, m2 i 64.3 ) .
In several instances it was possible to trace the course of individual , labeled intertectal axons .
Photomicrographs and reconstructions for two of these are provided in Figure 4A-D.
In all cases where axons could be followed across the midline , the course to the contralateral colliculus was fairly direct .
We saw no evidence of any local or descending collaterals in any of the cells in which we obtained extensive axonal labeling ( Fig . 4G ) .

Results.S: Autoradiographic experiments
autoradiographic data were in good agreement with from the HRP studies.

Injections of [3H]-leucine in the deep layers of the rostral one - half of the colliculus yielded extensive contralateral labeling , while injections in the deep - caudal portion of the tectum resulted in little or no labeling on the opposite side .
Injections restricted to the superficial layers never labeled the contralateral colliculus .
The essential results of our autoradiographic experiments are illustrated in Figure 5.

TTE.S: In HTN - 21 ( Fig . 5A , B , C ) L3H ] - leucine was deposited in the SGS and SO , 450 pm from the rostral border of the colliculus .
No transport across the midline was obtained in this hamster or in any of the four other animals which recevied similar injections.
In HTN-24 (Fig. 5D,E,F), an injection of virtually the same size was placed in the SGP, 400 pm from the anterior border of the colliculus.
In this animal , numerous labeled fibers could be seen coursing through the intercollicular commissure ( Fig . 5E ) and extensive labeling was visible in the deep layers of the contralateral tectum .
Contralateral collicular labeling was observed in all of the hamsters ( N = 8 ) which received injections in the rostroventral colliculus .
In HTN - 36, ( Fig . 5G , H , I ) , a large deposit of L3H1 - leucine centered 550 pm from the caudal collicular border was made into the SGS and SO .
No transport across the midline was observed.
Similar data were obtained from the other three hamsters which received injections restricted to the superficial layers in the caudal colliculus .
Five hamsters received injections which involved the deep layers in the caudal half of the colliculus .
The results from these cases were somewhat more variable than those described above.
In three animals, no transport across the midline was observed.
In two other cases a few labeled fibers were visible in the intertectal commisssure , but no terminal labeling could be seen in the contralateral colliculus .

Results.S: Data from one of these animals (HTN-29) are presented in Figure 5 (K,L,M).
Combined HRP - autoradiographic experiments

These experiments tested directly the reciprocity of intercollicular connections , and as expected from the results of the single tracer experiments , the labeled cells and radiolabel obtained here had a great deal of overlap .
However , HRP - filled fibers , presumably labeled by anterograde transport of the enzyme , were often visible well beyond the boundaries of the area encompassed by autoradiographic labeling .
With respect to the latter possibility , in several cases , anterograde transport of HRP revealed fibers which appeared to terminate in the SGS .

In a number of cases labeled fibers could be seen coursing dorsally out of the intermediate gray layer ( Fig . 8A ) and label ( Fig . 8B ) , similar to appearance to that interpreted by others ( e . g . , Land and Lund , ' 79 ) as axonal arbors , was observed in the superficial gray layer .
In a few favorable instances ( Fig . 8C ) individual fibers could be traced from the SGI , through the SO and into the SGS .
Superficial terminal labeling was never visible in our autoradiographic material .

The only injections ( N = 5 ) which yielded both labeled cells and radiolabel in the contralateral superior colliculus were those which included the deep layers in the rostral half of the colliculus .
In the HRP material a dense band of fibers could be seen crossing the midline ( Fig . 6A ) and a region of labeled cells and fibers was visible homotopic to the injection site ( Fig . 6B ) .

In an adjacent section processed for autoradiography , ( Fig . 6C , D ) a similar band of fibers could be seen crossing the midline and then expanding into a terminal zone in the contralateral colliculus .
The correspondence between the retrograde and anterograde labeling is illustrated in dorsal view reconstructions of four cases in Figure 7.
It is evident that in each case the correspondence between injection site and contralateral labeling appears much tighter in the autoradiographic material.

The results of the double - labeling experiments indicated that very few , if any , intertectal neurons contribute axons to the spinal or pontine reticular outputs of the colliculus .
In the five cases in which spinal NY injections were combined with collicular HRP deposits both HRP and NYlabeled cells were observed in the left superior colliculus .
No double - labeled cells were seen .
Similar results were obtained in the two cases where HRP was placed in a cervical spinal cut and NY was injected into the colliculus .
In the seven animals where collicular HRP deposits were combined with large pontine NY injections , a total of four double - labeled collicular neurons were obtained .
The results of one experiment in which a double - labeled cell was observed are illustrated in Figure 9.
The colllicular HRP deposit ( Fig . 9A ) in this case ( HTN - 55 ) was centered in the medial portion of the SGI .
The NY injection ( Fig . 9B ) encompassed most of the pons and was very dense in the region of the MLF .

Numerous NY and a small number of HRP - labeled cells were visible in the left superior colliculus ( Fig . 9C - fJ and neurons labeled with different tracers were often in close proximity ( Fig . 9E , F ) .
However, only one double-labeled cell (Fig. 9F, arrow) was observed.

TTE.S: In concluding this section it should be noted that in two preliminary experiments in which NY and HRP were injected together into the spinal cord , numerous double - labeled neurons were visible in the red nucleus , sensorimotor cortex , and superior colliculus .

Results.S: Sensory representation in the region of intertectal connections

The region which gave rise to and ; on the basis of the correspondence demonstrated above , received intertectal axons , encompassed the portion of the ipsilateral visual field mapped in the colliculus and the representation of the nasal two - thirds of the contralateral visual field .
The somatosensory representation of the hamster 's face and at least a portion of the neck was also included in the part of the colliculus where intertectal connections were demonstrated .

Plots of receptive field data from cases in which HRP and / or [ 3H ] - leucine injections labeled the contralateral superior colliculus are provided in Figure 10A and C , and receptive field data from instances in which no intertectal transport was obtained are illustrated in Figure 10B and D .
All of the cases shown are those in which injection sites were centered in the deep layers and were defined by single unit recordings .

As can be seen , there was relatively little overlap between the receptive fields recorded in cases where intertectal transport was obtained and those from the deposits which produced no labeling in the contralateral colliculus .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The results indicate that the hamster's intercollicular pathway reciprocally interconnects the rostra1 half of the deep tectal laminae and that the neurons whose axons compose this projection do not contribute collaterals to the spinal or pontine reticular outflow of the colliculus.
Before discussing the implications of these findings and their relationship with data from other laboratories, it is important to point out one potential source of error in our study.
It is well known that HRP can be taken up and transported by damaged fibers of passage (see, for examples, Kristensson and Olsson, '74; DeVito et al., '74).

This problem would appear to be particularly troublesome when attempting to examine intertectal connections since the colliculus is known to have a number of crossed outputs (see, for examples, Altman and Carpenter, '61; Kawamura et al., '74; Graham, '77; Harting, '77; Edwards and Henkel, '78).

While most of the contralateral, descending projections of the colliculus cross the midline in the dorsal tegmental decussation (see the above cited references) and would not have been included in our injections, Kawamura et al. ('74) did report that superior collicular lesions in cat resulted in degenerating fibers which could be traced through the intercollicular commissure to apparent termination in the dorsal portion of the mesencephalic reticular formation (also, see Altman and Carpenter, '61: Fig. 22; and Martin, '69).
Our autoradiographic experiments also demonstrated such a pathway when injection sites encompassed the lateral portion of the SGP.
It is thus possible that our deeper HRP deposits could have damaged and labeled some of these fibers and their parent cell bodies.
Edwards and Henkel ('78) have also noted that a few of the collicular axons which innervate the supraculomotor central gray cross in the collicular commissure.
We were unable to detect such axons in our material.

With respect to crossed, ascending collicular projections, Crain and Hall ('80) have shown that the caudal division of the lateral posterior nucleus is innervated by the contralateral superior colliculus.
However, the fibers composing this projection cross the midline in the supraoptic commissure and thus would not be involved in any of our injections.
The cells of origin of the intercollicular pathway
The present findings are in fairly good accord with the information available for other species.
In Galugo, Raczkowski and Diamond ('78) observed labeled cells in the SGI and SO following injections of HRP into the contralateral colliculus.
In cat, Edwards ('77) reported laminar and areal distributions for intertectal neurons very similar to those which we obtained with HRP deposits in the rostrul colliculus.
The data reported for cat by MagalhaesCastro et al. ('78) are somewhat different.
With anterior injections, one-third of the labeled cells in their material were in the superficial laminae of the rostra1 colliculus.
Interestingly, with posterior injections the total number of labeled cells was much lower, but the laminar distribution was much closer to that reported by Edwards ('77).
In our material, caudal HRP deposits yielded just the opposite result.
A significantly greater proportion of the labeled cells were in the SO and fewer labeled neurons were found in the SGI.
The morphology of intertectal neurons has not been described in detail by previous investigators.
Both Edwards ('77) and Magalhiies-Castro et al. ('78) noted that intertectal neurons in cat were "small or medium" in size.
The soma1 diameters of the cells in our material had a wide range, but the majority fell between 10 and 20 pm.
The dendritic filling obtained in our material demonstrated further that a wide variety of morphological cell types contributed axons to the intertectal pathway.
Insofar as morphological variety implies functional diversity, this would suggest that intertectal neurons might be relatively heterogeneous in terms of their response characteristics.
Recordings from a limited number of such cells (Rhoades et al., '81) have also suggested that this is the case.
The terminal distribution of the intercollicular pathway
The hamster's intercollicular projection terminated almost entirely in the deep layers of the colliculus in a manner that was symmetrical with the locus of the injection site.
This is in general agreement with the data from other species (Edwards, '77; Graham, '77; Harting, '77; Altman and Carpenter, '61; Martin, '69; Rafols and Matzke, '70).
There are, however, two differences between our data and those from the studies noted above.
First, we saw no evidence of axons of superior collicular origin crossing the midline in what Bucher and Burgi ('50) referred to as the tectal semidecussation.
Such fibers have been reported in cat (Edwards, '77) and opossum (Martin, '60; Rafols and Matzke, '70).
Secondly, in several HRP experiments we found evidence of intertectal terminations in the SGS, just below the collicular surface.
Such labeled fibers were not visible in our autoradiographic material and the existence of terminal labeling in the SGS was specifically denied by Edwards ('77).
Kawamura et al. ('74: Fig. 3) did, however, indicate some weak superficial layer degeneration following contralateral collicular lesions in cat.

It has been shown in cat (Powell, '76; Berman and Payne, '80; Payne and Berman, '81) that a crossed corticotectal projection courses through the intercollicular commissure and terminates in the superficial laminae.
Such a projection has not, however, been observed in the hamster (Rhoades and Chalupa, '78).

The only other source of crossed input to the superficial laminae which has been well established is that from the parabigeminal nucleus (Graybiel, '78; Edwards et al., '79; Baleydier and Magnin, '79; Watanabe and Kawana, '79; Sherk, '791, and these fibers cross the midline in the supraoptic, rather than the intertectal, commissure (Graybiel, '78; Watanabe and Kawana, '79).
It thus seems reasonable to suggest that the HRP-labeled fibers in our material were of collicular origin, and that the intertectal pathway may innervate, albeit quite weakly, the SGS.
Sensory representation encompassed by the intertectal pathway

HRP and/or r3H]-leucine injection sites which gave rise to intercollicular transport in our experiments were associated with visual receptive fields almost as far temporal as the representation of the optic disk.
The somatosensory representation of the entire head and a portion of the neck was also encompassed by intertectal connections.
These findings vary somewhat from those reported for the cat.

Magalhhes-Castro et al. ('78) reported that the vast majority of the labeled cells in their material were located in the portion of the colliculus representing the ipsilateral visual field.3 When their anatomical findings are fitted to the somatosensory collicular representation provided by Stein et al.
Magalhaiies-Castro and Kruger ('76), only the region in which the nose and mouth are mapped contains labeled cells.
In Edward's ('77) experiments, labeling indicative of intertectal connections included the rostra1 40% of the colliculus.
This would encompass the representation of the ipsilateral, and 10-15" of the contralateral, visual field, and the somatosensory representation of the head and perhaps a part of the neck.

The portion of the visual field encompassed by intertectal connections in cat and hamster is thus very different, whereas the part of the somatosensory map which gives rise to and receives intercollicular axons is very similar in the two species.

That this difference and similarity exist at the same time results from the fact that the portion of the colliculus subtended by the representation of the head and neck is very similar in cat (Stein et al., '76) and hamster (Finlay et al. '78; Rhoades, 'go), while the magnification of the central visual field is much greater in the former species (compare the data of Feldon et al., '70; and Lane et al., '74; with those of Finlay et al., '78; and Rhoades, '80).

If the development of intertectal connections is determined by one or more of the sensory representations in the colliculus and this determination is similar for the hamster and cat (the only species for which detailed information regarding both collicular sensory topography, and intertectal connections are available), then it seems likely that it is the somatosensory, rather than the visual collicular representation, which is important for the organization of intertectal pathway during development.

This argument is supported by the fact that most intertectal neurons which possess sensory receptive fields are somatosensory rather than visual (Rhoades et al., W), and the additional finding that neonatal enucleation, a manipulation which alters the topography of the visual, but not the somatosensory representation in the colliculus ipsilateral to the remaining eye (Rhoades, '80), has no readily apparent effect on the organization of intercollicular connections (Rhoades and Fish, experiments in progress).
Given the present findings, it is surprising that Nagata et al. ('80) were unable to demonstrate intercollicular connections in rabbit.

These investigators argued that intercollicular connections are likely to be present only in animals with an extensive representation of the ipsilateral hemifield and/or a large proportion of binocular neurons at the collicular level.
Our data militate strongly against this generalization.

The ipsilateral visual field representation in hamster (Finlay et al., '78; Rhoades, '80) appears no more extensive than that in rabbit (Hughes, '71), and there are also very few binocular cells in the hamster's tectum (Chalupa and Rhoades, '77; Finlay et al., '78; Stein and Dixon, '79).
Functional role of the intertectal pathway

Possible functional roles of the intercollicular pathway have been discussed by Edwards ('771, and he has suggested, as did Sprague ('66), that this projection may mediate suppressive interactions between the colliculi, and further that these connections may be involved primarily in the organization of the motor output of the colliculus, both with respect to the generation of small (e.g., tracking) eye movements and perhaps also orientation to extravisual stimuli.

That stimulation of the intercollicular pathway monosynaptically inhibits contralateral, tectoreticular, and tectospinal neurons in cat has now been established unequivocally by the intracellular recordings of Maeda et al. ('79).
Our own extracellular recordings in hamster (Fish and Rhoades, '81b) have demonstrated that collicular stimulation can markedly suppress the responsivity of neurons in the contralateral tectum.

While most of the cells influenced by contralateral collicular shocks in our sample were located in the deep laminae and were responsive to extravisual stimulation, the activity of a number of exclusively visual, superficial layer neurons was completely suppressed by such stimulation.

Our methods were not sufficient to differentiate monofrom polysynaptic connections, but the data do suggest that one colliculus may influence not only the organization of motor output in deep laminae, but also the processing of sensory input in the superficial layers of its contralateral partner.
